title: Cathie Wood Drops JAW-DROPPING Prediction

And so what what's what's your timeline look like? And what how does that matter? Well, that that honeymoon phase right now uh at least as as to what the market is saying is quite quite long. The reality is is that you know we're only going to see initial production of what's more of a uh a closer to uh production version later this this year, right? As opposed to the prototype version that that we've had. So this is still very much in uh improving the concept phase. I think what the market really is focused on though is is the TAN capabilities. We just point out you went to CES a few weeks ago. Uh there are any number of other Chinese players that have humanoid robots. You have uh Boston Dynamics. Tesla obviously does have an AI advantage. She's talking about some of the the opportunities or the advantages on supply chain hand design and is actually a really tricky part of this. They've got the battery piece, right? That's why I think Tesla is being given uh a significant benefit here from from the market's perspective. >> Tesla's cost advantage in robo taxi is structural and permanent. They can put a vehicle on the road for a fifth of what it costs Whimo. So Dan's making a point that sounds simple but actually has massive implications. Each Whimo costs somewhere between $100 and $150,000 to put on the road. They don't make the vehicles themselves. They have to buy them from another company and that company takes a profit. Then Whimo has to outfit them with LAR, radar, and all these sensors. Cybercap, Tesla can probably build those for anywhere between 20 and $30,000. So that's a 5x cost difference before you even turn the car on. And this matters for how you actually run a robo taxi business. If you're Whimo and you want to meet peak demand, rush hour, people leaving bars at 2 a.m. big events, you need a massive fleet of idle vehicles sitting around doing nothing for almost all the time. That's terrible capital allocation. Tesla can afford to flood a city with cyber cabs because the cost of having one sit there waiting is almost nothing compared to what Whimo pays. Higher utilization, lower costs, better margins. The math just works differently. The LAR versus vision debate is still playing out. And I think Dan's right that Tesla still has to prove this works more broadly. But I do think they are pretty much there. Whimo is operating fully driverless in three or four cities now, but Tesla has that scalability advantage, which I think they're on the cusp of really ramping into. And that's because Tesla has just pulled the driver in Austin on a limited basis. But the thing is, even if we assume both systems achieve comparable safety and comparable weight times, meaning the service itself is identical from a customer's perspective, the cost structure still favors Tesla by a massive margin. You can't innovate your way out of paying five times more for your hardware. Plus, there's the fleet scaling problem. And this is key. It's being trained on Nvidia Blackwell chips. That matters because Blackwell is supposed to change what's possible at the very top of model training. GPT6 is expected in the second quarter trained on Nvidia's Blackwell chips and if it resets the benchmarks the way Gemini did, that changes the narrative again. But this is something which changes things. I think Microsoft isn't positioned to capture most of the upside anymore. Amy Herd pointed out on the earnings call that the backlog mix is now 55% Microsoft, 45% tied to OpenAI. That's a lot of exposure to a company Microsoft doesn't control and is actively diversifying away from. The other thing worth watching is OpenAI's actual business fundamentals. If you look at the numbers floating around, they're spending about $169 for every dollar they earn. The projections I've seen suggest they could be running at losses of tens of billions of dollars or more per year by 2028, as high as $40 billion. Compare that to Google, which is $34 billion in net profit last quarter alone. Open AAI doesn't have a sustainable business model that prints money. They have a product that requires constant fundraising to survive. It's a very different risk profile than investing in Microsoft or Google or Amazon, companies that are profitable despite their AI spending. And then there's the competitive pressure from multiple directions. Gemini has been eating into ChatG's market share went from about 8% to roughly 25% of the market. Claude from Anthropic keeps climbing the benchmarks. Microsoft is giving customers more choice which models they use. So even if GPT6 is great, OpenAI has to defend market share against wellunded competitors while burning billions of dollars. The question for investors is if they can build a sustainable business before the money runs out. Finally, let's see Kathy Wood and the members from the Moonshot podcast discuss the big impact that robo taxi might have on the global economy. This is a banger. >> You know, the one that came up with Elon, I don't know if you watched the whole Elon podcast, but I couldn't believe he told that story about the two economists walking through the woods and they pay each other to eat and it adds $200 to the global economy, but [laughter] nothing productive is created. And and that dubtales with Selen's law, you know, which is, hey, if if AI cures breast cancer, and millions and millions of people don't need radi, you know, radio um radiation or chemotherapy, that has the effect of looking like it reduces the GDP. In reality, if you wanted to, you could still go and hang out, you know, and not get the radiation and pay if you wanted to and then not have the cancer. And so it it adds huge net value to the world obviously, but it shows up as negative GDP. So the so the GDP metric is fundamentally broken in the age of AI.
